tower.metaTitle: The Tower Tour | St. Nikolaus Tower Tour
tower.title: The Tower Tour
tower.intro: The tower tour offers an exciting climbing experience through several levels all the way to the top of the tower. The tower consists of 10 floors, each providing a unique experience.

experience.v: Stairs, historic relics, bells, top view

tip.v: Hands free, light backpack, close-fitting clothing

step1.title: The climb begins
step1.text: The tour starts with classic twisted metal stairs. As you move upwards, wooden stairs become more common. These are a mix of older and newer wood as a result of renovations. Switching to wood helps reduce the overall weight of the tower.
step1.cap1: Lower sections include classic metal stairs.
step1.cap2: Wooden stairs appear higher up as part of renovations.

step2.title: Narrow stairs and symbolism
step2.text: On the lower floors (2–4), the stairs are wider. The higher you climb, the narrower they become. This is not random—the narrow stairs reflect the Biblical verse: “Enter through the narrow gate.” (Matthew 7:13). The ancient cast-iron door from the 1300s conveys a similar message.
step2.cap1: Historic elements encountered along the way.
step2.cap2: Timber engineering in the attic area.

step3.title: Upper floors and key attractions
step3.text: As the climb continues, visitors encounter various highlights: the baselbalg, the attic, the bells, and finally the top view. Modern safety features are integrated throughout the tower, including a fire protection system and air purification technology used after church rituals.
step3.cap1: Baselbalg: the wooden blower that supplies air to the organ.
step3.cap2: The wooden bell frame provides flexibility and structural protection.

safety.title: Safety and comfort
safety.text: Please climb carefully, keep both hands free whenever possible, and take extra care on narrow stairs—especially when carrying a backpack. Visitors are advised to wear close-fitting clothing. Loose garments and open jacket pockets may get caught on stairs or railings.

tower.outro1: The view over Rosenheim and the fresh air on the 10th level feel like a true reward. The effort of the final steps shows that the destination must be earned. At the top, visitors enjoy clean air and an almost 360-degree view over the city—one of the tour’s main highlights.
tower.outro2: The early church builders were highly skilled and intelligent people. Their craftsmanship was passed down through generations. Although the church has been renovated several times, later builders respectfully followed traditional methods—something truly worth experiencing firsthand.

topView.metaTitle: The Top View | St. Nikolaus Tower Tour
topView.title: The Top View
topView.intro: According to visitors and organizers, the top view of Rosenheim is the most compelling attraction. It offers a wonderful bird’s-eye view of the beautifully organized city.
topView.heroCaption: A wide panorama over Rosenheim from the top level of the St. Nikolaus Church tower.
topView.p1: Most visitors come from Rosenheim and nearby towns. Many are used to living in one- to two-storey houses, so seeing the city from a height comparable to ten storeys offers a completely new perspective.
topView.p2:
On clear, sunny days, the nearby Alps are often visible without any equipment. Since there are no taller buildings nearby, the view opens up widely and helps broaden the mind and thoughts.

As mentioned in the Tower Tour section, the climb can be a bit challenging, with steep and narrow stairs. For many sport-loving visitors, this is part of the fun. After climbing ten floors, blood circulation improves, which helps sharpen the senses. This makes the wide view even more enjoyable. At this height, the air feels fresher and cleaner. Together, these effects create a memorable experience that many visitors would happily repeat. It is also a perfect place to take spectacular photos and surprise friends and family.
topView.splitCaption: Through old traditional windows, visitors can experience the colorful outside view.
topView.highlightsTitle: What makes the top view special

alps.title: Alps on clear days
alps.text: On a clear, sunny day, the Alps can be seen in the distance, making the view feel expansive and memorable.

roofs.title: Rooftops and city layout
roofs.text: Many houses have colored roofs and mostly one-storey structures. From above, this creates a clearly organized and beautiful cityscape.

air.title: Fresh air and reward
air.text: After the climb, the open air at the top feels like a reward and refreshes the senses.

photos.title: Perfect for photos
photos.text: A great place to take spectacular, unique photos and share them with friends and family.

topView.quote: “For many visitors, this is the most compelling attraction of the tour.”

strip.cap1: The top of the tower is built with wood and finished with copper. This reduces weight and increases longevity.
strip.cap2: Wooden flooring improves safety, especially in wet weather.
strip.cap3: The roof is also made of wood and features decorative graphics.

topView.outro: After climbing through all floors and experiencing many attractions, the open and fresh top area feels truly rewarding. With sharper senses and fresh air, visitors often want to return again.

bells.metaTitle: The Bells | St. Nikolaus Tower Tour
bells.title: The Bells
bells.intro: The bells are one of the most interesting elements of the tower tour. There are 7 bells in total. They are placed on the 9th floor. They are maintained by electronic motors that are programmed with software to deliver the intended rhythm. All bells can be operated individually or together to create a beautiful rhythmic sound.The smallest bell, the Sterbeglocke with the highest tone (fs²), is also the oldest bell. It was cast in 1606 by Bartholomeus Wengle in Augsburg. The other six bells were cast in 1947 by Czudnochowsky in Erding. The largest bell with the deepest tone (b⁰), the Dreifaltigkeitsglocke (Trinity Bell), weighs 3,100 kilograms.
bells.heroCap1: Trinity bell and the bell chamber: timber beams, controlled mechanics, and carefully balanced movement.

bell1.title: Trinity Bell
bell1.inscription: “Mich goß Czudnochowsky, J. Bachmairs Nachfolger zu Erding” / “Mit my voice I praise God, the Triune”

bells.story1Text: Due to a renovation mistake in the past, the wooden bell frame (Glockenstuhl) was removed and replaced with a concrete frame. This resulted in a lack of elasticity, which is essential for the movement of the bells.Bells are heavy, and their swinging transfers force into the tower. A wooden bell frame provides elasticity and reduces stress on masonry. When rigid materials such as concrete are used, they cannot absorb the vibration adequately, making cracks in the tower walls more likely.
bells.story1Caption: Elastic wooden frames absorb motion, reducing stress on masonry.
bells.story2Text: After several years of vibration and structural deterioration, another renovation took place. The upper part of the tower (which was most affected by vibration) was dismantled and rebuilt. The wooden Glockenstuhl was restored instead of concrete to ensure elasticity. This is a clear example of how wood can be superior to rigid materials under certain conditions.
bells.story2Caption: The tower was dismantled and rebuilt to restore safety and harmony.
bells.noteP1: During the reconstruction of the tower in 1950, workers discovered a sealed metal box hidden inside the structure. The box, dated 1784, contained a relic of an unknown martyr, handwritten blessings, and prayers asking for protection of the church and the city.
bells.noteP2: After reconstruction, the contents were returned to the tower together with contemporary documents from 1950, continuing a long-standing tradition of safeguarding the church through faith and memory.
bells.ctaText: Book a tour and experience the bell chamber up close—sound, engineering, and history high above the city. Available from Easter Sunday to the end of October each year.

baselbalg.metaTitle: Baselbalg (The Bellow) | St. Nikolaus Tower Tour
baselbalg.title: Baselbalg (the Bellow)
baselbalg.intro:
St. Nikolaus Church houses a large and powerful pipe organ, whose sound depends entirely on a continuous and precisely regulated supply of air. This air is produced by the Baselbalg (bellows), a traditional wooden mechanism that forms the silent foundation of the organ’s voice.

Unlike modern electric systems, the Baselbalg works through carefully engineered layers of wood that rise and fall slowly, storing and releasing air at a constant pressure. This gentle, rhythmic motion ensures that each pipe speaks evenly, preserving both pitch stability and tonal warmth.

Visible during the tower tour, the Baselbalg offers a rare insight into historic organ craftsmanship, reminding visitors that the grandeur of the organ’s sound is made possible by a quiet, almost invisible system working continuously in the background.
baselbalg.kv1Value: Around the 3rd level of the tower
baselbalg.heroCaption: The organ of St. Nikolaus Church.
baselbalg.s1Text: The Baselbalg provides a continuous and steady airflow that allows the organ to speak clearly and evenly. Without this stable air supply, pitch would fluctuate and the characteristic sound of the organ would be lost.
baselbalg.s2Title: 2) Built in wood, engineered for silence
baselbalg.s2Text: The system is almost entirely made of wood and consists of four stacked layers. These layers move slowly and quietly, rising and falling to generate the airflow required for the organ pipes. This gentle mechanical movement helps preserve the organ’s traditional sound quality.
baselbalg.s3Text: St. Nikolaus Church regularly hosts organ concerts. The music is performed by an experienced musical ensemble of around 20 musicians and singers led by Mr. Christopher Ryser. The repertoire includes classical works (especially J. S. Bach), choral compositions from the 16th and 17th centuries, and contemporary sacred music. An organ concert takes place every Saturday at 12:00 noon. Everyone is welcome, admission is free, and donations are encouraged and appreciated.
baselbalg.s4Text: The large and impressive organ was built by the company Reil from the Netherlands and installed in the church on December 6, 2009 (St. Nicholas Day). Since then, its sound has become an integral part of the church’s liturgy. The chest organ in the chancel was built by the German company Linder from Nußdorf am Inn.
baselbalg.quoteTitle: A quiet system with a powerful effect
baselbalg.quoteText: The Baselbalg is neither dramatic nor loud, yet it is essential to the organ’s sound. Its steady, silent motion is a reminder that true craftsmanship often works best when it remains in the background.
baselbalg.ctaText: Book a tour and discover the hidden mechanics that keep the organ alive. Available from Easter Sunday to the end of October, every year.

churchTour.metaTitle: Church Tour | St. Nikolaus Tower Tour
churchTour.title: The Church Tour
churchTour.intro:
The church tour is an essential part of the overall experience and often serves as the starting point of the visit.
Before ascending the tower, guests are invited to enter the prayer hall and become familiar with the spiritual and architectural heart of St. Nikolaus Church.

Visitors can take time to observe the interior architecture: the high vaulted ceilings, balanced proportions, and carefully guided light that together create a sense of clarity and reverence.
Sitting quietly on the wooden benches allows guests to pause, slow down, and experience the atmosphere of the space as it has developed over centuries.

The tour also offers moments for reflection on the artworks, religious symbols, and relics found throughout the church.
Each element tells a story of faith, protection, and community life, helping visitors understand how the church interior and the tower together formed a place of worship, refuge, and identity for the city.
churchTour.heroCaption: A calm introduction before the tower climb: light, space, and sacred art.
churchTour.step1Title: Arrive and take in the nave
churchTour.step1Text: The high vaults and long central aisle define the atmosphere. Visitors can orient themselves, observe the stained glass, and experience how sound and silence interact within the space.
churchTour.step2Text: The tour highlights selected artworks and relics. Many pieces reflect Baroque devotion and local history, shaped by centuries of faith, hardship, and restoration.
churchTour.step3Title: Connect the church to the tower story
churchTour.step3Text: The interior is more than a beautiful hall: it explains why the tower mattered and connects community life, craftsmanship, and the rhythm of liturgy and music.
churchTour.spotlightTitle: A historic altar artwork watching over the city
churchTour.spotlightText1:
Visitors encounter the oldest known artwork of Rosenheim, which still serves as the current altarpiece. The historic painting was created in 1667 by Antonio Domenico Trivia, who later became the court artist of Munich.

Behind the high altar hangs one of the oldest surviving artworks in Rosenheim.
Created in the early 17th century, the painting depicts Mary with the Christ Child, accompanied by St. Nicholas and St. Sebastian, overlooking the city of Rosenheim.
The artwork reflects the deep faith of its time and the belief in divine protection during an era marked by hardship, fire, and disease.
Despite numerous reconstructions of the church, the painting has remained in its place for centuries and continues to watch over the city.
churchTour.spotlightText2: The artwork embodies the faith of its era and the hope for protection during times shaped by hardship, fire, and disease. Despite later reconstructions of the church, it has remained in its place for centuries.
churchTour.railCap1: A quiet moment inside the prayer hall, where light, space, and faith meet.
churchTour.railCap2: Mosaic depicting the enthroned Virgin Mary.
churchTour.organTitle: The organ and the two-level interior
churchTour.organText:
At the rear of the main prayer hall, the large organ is visible and mounted against the wall.
The interior is divided into two levels: the lower floor is dedicated to prayer and liturgy, while the upper level accommodates musicians, singers, and the organ player.
churchTour.ctaText: Book a tour and experience the church interior before the tower climb. Available from Easter Sunday to the end of October, every year.

dachboden.title: Attic
dachboden.subtitle: A calm, wooden “in-between” space where structure, silence, and history become visible.
dachboden.heroCaption: The attic reveals the craftsmanship of the timber frames—quiet, spacious, and peaceful.
dachboden.quoteText: The old cast iron door reminds us of the Biblical phrase “enter through the narrow gate”. The attic’s entry feels narrow, then suddenly opens into a wider space. That contrast makes the experience a rewarding one.
dachboden.section1Text1: The attic is defined by its timber geometry: beams, joints, and frames that carry the roof are all made from wood, without using much metal. Even when the space is mostly empty, the structure itself becomes the main exhibit. The smell of wood, the silence, and the wide space together create a unique feeling.
dachboden.section1Text2:
According to the organizer, wood was chosen not only for aesthetics, but also for practical strength-to-weight performance and durability across centuries.

The attic also appears to be a place where a peaceful pause can be made after already climbing several floors. A little rest while walking through the place makes one prepared for the upcoming events.
dachboden.section1Cap1: Angled frames and long sightlines make the attic feel larger and spacious.
dachboden.section1Cap2: One can already see the beautiful town from the windows of the attic.
dachboden.section2Text1: The entry point is an old iron door set into thick stone. Its proportions and material hint at medieval building methods - compact, defensive, and built for endurance.
dachboden.section2Text2: After passing the narrow entry, the space opens. This immediate expansion creates a strong contrast of “compression and release” in how visitors experience the place.
dachboden.section2Cap: The old entry door from 1300s: a small threshold that changes how you perceive the space beyond it.
dachboden.section3Text1: There is a special stone plate with historical German writing (known as Frühneuhochdeutsch). The stone plate describes the chronological history of the church and the tower. It reminds us of the older time when writing special texts on stone plates was a respectable practice. Even without reading every line, the typography and material presence communicate age and seriousness.
dachboden.section3Text2: Nearby, additional plaques and smaller elements create a compact “micro-museum” inside the attic.
dachboden.grid1Text: A formal record engraved in stone, written in Frühneuhochdeutsch.
dachboden.grid2Text: A historical stone plate referring to the Church of the Holy Spirit.
dachboden.grid3Text: Remnants of practical systems used during church rituals and maintenance.
dachboden.section4Text1: There are two falcons who live in the church (one nest in the attic, another nest is even above, near the clock). The organizers made considerable efforts to make the birds feel welcome and at home. Careful window design and nesting arrangements ensure free movement of the birds while keeping the building safe, especially in the wet season.
dachboden.section4Text2: This detail shows a thoughtful balance of heritage preservation, building safety, and respect for living nature in the same place.
dachboden.section4Cap1: Comfortable and safe nest of the falcon in the attic.
dachboden.section4Cap2: Window setup with a deliberate gap ensures the free movement of the bird and building safety in wet seasons.
